talks/2012/cuny_2011.title: How to Construct a Minimal Theory of Mind

talks/2012/dubrovnik_2011.title: Talking About and Seeing Blue
talks/2012/dubrovnik_2011.summary: Categorical perception is a pervasive and useful feature of human experience much neglected by philosophers despite illuminating psychological research on this topic.

talks/2012/glasgow_2012.title: Intention and Motor Representation in Action Explanation

talks/2012/heidelberg_2011.title: Mindreading and Joint Action
talks/2012/heidelberg_2011.summary: In this talk I present some research on minimal theory of mind, on joint action and on relations between the two.

talks/2012/intention_and_motor_represent.title: Intention and Motor Representation in Joint Action
talks/2012/intention_and_motor_represent.summary: On the assumption that social motor representation plays a role in explaining how effective joint action is possible, is there also a role for motor representation in explaining what joint action is?

talks/2012/intention_and_motor_represent.title: Intention and Motor Representation in Joint Action

talks/2012/joint_action_and_the_emergenc.title: Joint Action and the Emergence of Mindreading

talks/2012/lyon_2012.title: Intention and Motor Representation in Explaining Action

talks/2012/milan_2011.title: Joint Action: Conceptual Tools for Scientific Research

talks/2012/minimal_theory_of_mind_cambri.title: Minimal Theory of Mind: How to Measure Mental States

talks/2012/motor_representation_shared_i.title: Motor Representation and Shared Intention
talks/2012/motor_representation_shared_i.summary: On the assumption that motor representation plays a role in explaining how effective joint action is possible, do we also need motor representation to explain what joint action is?

talks/2012/nijmegen_2011.title: Joint Action and Knowing Others' Minds

talks/2012/paris_2011.title: Joint Action and the Emergence of Mindreading
talks/2012/paris_2011.summary: How can we explain the emergence, in evolution or development, of sophisticated forms of theory of mind cognition? One conjecture is that their emergence somehow involves joint action (Knoblich & Sebanz, 2006; Hughes & Leekam, 2004; Moll & Tomasello, 2007). This raises two questions.

talks/2012/shared_agency_and_motor_repre.title: Shared Agency and Motor Representation
talks/2012/shared_agency_and_motor_repre.summary: Shared agency is paradigmatically involved when two or more people paint a house together, tidy the toys away together, or lift a two-handled basket together. To characterise shared agency, some philosophers have appealed to a special kind of intention or structure of intention, knowledge or commitment often called shared intention'.

talks/2012/stirling_2012.title: Minimal Theory of Mind and Joint Action

talks/2012/tuebingen_2011.title: Which Joint Actions Ground Social Cognition
talks/2012/tuebingen_2011.summary: Several researchers have conjectured that joint action partially explains how sophisticated forms of cognition emerge in development or evolution (for example, Knoblich & Sebanz 2006; Moll & Tomasello 2007). If any such conjecture is correct, what could joint action be?

talks/2013/collective_agency_oxford.title: Collective Agency and Knowledge of Others’ Minds
talks/2013/collective_agency_oxford.summary: When friends walk together, they typically exercise collective agency. By contrast, two strangers walking side by side exercise parallel but merely individual agency. This and other contrasts invite the question, What distinguishes collective agency from parallel but merely individual agency?

talks/2013/metacognition_and_mindreading.title: Monitoring and Controlling the Mental States of Others
talks/2013/metacognition_and_mindreading.summary: The success of infants and nonhuman animals on some belief reasoning tasks may be best explained by a cognitively efficient but inflexible capacity for tracking belief-like states. In humans, this capacity persists in parallel with a later-developing, more flexible but more cognitively demanding theory-of-mind abilities.

talks/2013/motor_representation_in_joint.title: Motor Representation in Joint Action
talks/2013/motor_representation_in_joint.summary: What do recent findings about mechanisms for interpersonal coordination reveal about the nature of joint action? Joint action paradigmatically occurs when two or more people paint a house together, tidy the toys away together, or lift a two-handled basket.

talks/2013/not_just_wide_but_shared.title: Not Just Wide but Shared: Joint Action Is a Core Form of Social Intelligence

talks/2013/perceiving_anger_and_sharing_.title: Perceiving Anger and Sharing Smiles: The Roles of Perception and Social Interaction in Acquiring Knowledge of Others’ Mental States
talks/2013/perceiving_anger_and_sharing_.summary: How could we come to know that another is angry about an obstacle she has encountered, or that she is happy about an outcome? Some such knowledge is uncontroversially acquired by inference. However, some philosophers have recently defended the hypothesis that knowledge of others' anger or joy might be acquired by perceiving it (e. g.

talks/2013/planning_for_collective_agenc.title: Planning for Collective Agency
talks/2013/planning_for_collective_agenc.summary: What does exercising collective agency require when our acting collectively is intentional? On the leading, best developed account, Michael Bratman's, intentional collective agency requires shared intention and shared intention is explained in terms of interconnected planning.

talks/2013/two_systems_two_theories.title: Two Systems and Two Theories of Mind
talks/2013/two_systems_two_theories.summary: We argue that mindreading involves not only multiple systems but also multiple models (or theories) of the mind. The argument turns on three questions. First, how could mindreading be both flexible and efficient? We suggest that, in a sense it can't.

talks/2014/joint_action_without_mindread.title: Joint Action without Mindreading
talks/2014/joint_action_without_mindread.summary: Joint action is a familiar feature of everyday life. Paradigmatic joint actions include things like painting a house together, walking together and playing a piano duet. On leading accounts of joint action, engaging in joint action presupposes mindreading abilities. But are there forms of joint action engaging in which would not require mindreading?

talks/2014/minimal_models_magdeburg.title: Minimal Models of the Physical and of the Mental: Processes, Representations and  Signature Limits
talks/2014/minimal_models_magdeburg.summary: This talk introduces a series of hypotheses and claims about the systems and models involved in mindreading (or ‘theory of mind’), explains how they generate predictions by drawing a parallel with cognition of physical properties like momentum, and highlights some recent evidence indicating that some of the hypotheses may be correct.

talks/2014/naturalising_joint_actions.title: Naturalising Joint Actions
talks/2014/naturalising_joint_actions.summary: Joint action is a familiar feature of everyday life. Paradigmatic cases include moving objects together, walking together and playing piano duets.

talks/2015/berlin_2015_core_knowledge.title: Only Phenomenal Expectations Connect Core Knowledge of Objects to Thought
talks/2015/berlin_2015_core_knowledge.summary: Infants have core knowledge of objects, causes, numbers, actions and much else besides (Spelke, 2003; Carey, 2009). But what is core knowledge? There are challenges which apply to the leading theoretical accounts (compare Butterfill, 2007; Keren and Schul, 2009; Adolphs, 2010).

talks/2015/bochum_2015.title: Acting Together: Motor Representation and Cooperation

talks/2015/bupdapest_moseo.title: Commentary on Wolfgang Prinz and Michael Graziano

talks/2015/copenhagen_2015.title: Acting Together and Acting As One

talks/2015/mindreading_espp.title: How Do Mindreaders Model Minds?
talks/2015/mindreading_espp.summary: "What it is to be a mindreader? Mindreading involves identifying mental states; this requires having some model of the mental, much as identifying physical states requires having some model of the physical.

talks/2015/mindreading_srcd.title: Systems, Models and Signature Limits
talks/2015/mindreading_srcd.summary: "Two puzzles about mindreading, and in particular the nature of belief ascription, require resolution. Can infants ascribe false beliefs in their first or second year of life? Some measures indicate that they can, others that they cannot. Is belief ascription automatic? Some findings suggest that it is, others that it is not.

talks/2015/practical_reasoning_motor_rep.title: Introduction to the Workshop on Practical Reasoning and Motor Representation

talks/2015/purposive_action_and_intentio.title: Purposive Action from Motor Representation to Intention

talks/2016/berlin_2016_2systems.title: How to Distinguish Two (Or More) Systems for Social Cognition
talks/2016/berlin_2016_2systems.summary: Suppose you observe two exercises of competence in social cognition and want to know whether the systems underpinning the exercises are the same or distinct. How can you tell?

talks/2016/milan_2016_core_knowledge.title: Core Knowledge, Phenomenal Expectations and Thought
talks/2016/milan_2016_core_knowledge.summary: How is core knowledge linked to full-blown thought and intentional action? Infants in the first months of life have core knowledge of objects, causes, numbers, actions and much else besides (Spelke, 2003; Carey, 2009). But what is core knowledge?

talks/2016/perceiving_mental_states_tueb.title: Perceiving Mental States
talks/2016/perceiving_mental_states_tueb.summary: How could we come to know that another is angry about an insult or happy about an outcome? Some philosophers have defended the hypothesis that knowledge of others' anger or joy is sometimes perceptual (e. g. Smith, 2010, 2015; McNeill, 2012a,b). In this talk I consider two challenges to this hypothesis.

talks/2022/warwick_2022_open_day.title: Who Is Morally Responsible for Global Poverty?

talks/2023/goettingen_2023_inferential_i.title: Inferential Isolation Is a Barrier to Understanding Cognitive Development

talks/2023/milan_2023.title: Norm-like Patterns in Joint Action: A dual-process theory

talks/2023/munich_2023.title: Minimal Virtues: From Mindreading to Ethics via Joint Action (Munich)

talks/2023/potsdam_2023.title: Is There a Role for Metacognitive Feelings in Cognitive Development?

talks/2024/colyton_grammar_2024.title: How do we develop knowledge of physical objects?

talks/2025/ceu_vienna_2025.title: Joint Action at the Roots of Ethical Cognition

teaching/central_themes.title: Untitled
teaching/central_themes.summary: --- title: "Central Themes in Philosophy" url: "https://central-themes. butterfill. com/" authors: Stephen A. Butterfill year: 2019-20 term: Spring place: University of Warwick, UK abstract: | This is an introductory course covering six themes.

teaching/descartes.title: Untitled
teaching/descartes.summary: --- title: "Descartes" url: "https://descartes. butterfill. com/" authors: Stephen A. Butterfill year: 2018-2019 term: Spring place: University of Warwick, UK abstract: | This is an unorthodox introduction to Descartes’ Meditations for undergraduates.

teaching/joint_action.title: Joint Action
teaching/joint_action.summary: is a familiar feature of everyday life: people move tables together, walk together, play piano duets and cooperatively rear babies. For social (and eusocial) animals, effective joint action is necessary for survival. It also arguably explains the emergence, in evolution or development, of sophisticated cognitive capacities.

teaching/joint_action_and_the_emergence.title: Joint Action and the Emergence of Mindreading
teaching/joint_action_and_the_emergence.summary: How can we explain the emergence, in evolution or development, of mindreading? Some conjecture that its emergence involves joint action (Knoblich & Sebanz, 2006; Moll & Tomasello, 2007). Reflection on objections to this conjecture reveals mistakes in leading philosophical accounts of both mindreading and joint action.

teaching/logic_1.title: Logic 1
teaching/logic_1.summary: An introduction to first order logic for undergraduate students, concluding with informal proofs of soundness and completeness.

teaching/mind_and_reality.title: Untitled
teaching/mind_and_reality.summary: --- title: "Mind and Reality" url: "https://mind-and-reality. butterfill. com/" authors: Stephen A.

teaching/mindreading_and_joint_action.title: Mindreading and Joint Action: Philosophical Tools
teaching/mindreading_and_joint_action.summary: This course will introduce a variety of new and established philosophical ideas that might usefully inform experimental research on mindreading or on joint action (or both) but have so far been neglected or misunderstood by cognitive scientists. Starting from foundational questions like What is a mental state? and Which events are actions?

teaching/moral-psychology.title: Untitled
teaching/moral-psychology.summary: --- title: "Moral Psychology: The Science of Good and Evil? " url: "https://moral-psychology. butterfill. com/" authors: Stephen A.

teaching/origins_of_mind.title: Origins of Mind
teaching/origins_of_mind.summary: How do humans first come to know about— and to knowingly manipulate—objects, causes, words, numbers, colours, actions and minds?

teaching/origins_of_mind_with_richard.title: Origins of Mind (v2)
teaching/origins_of_mind_with_richard.summary: How do humans first come to know about— and to knowingly manipulate—objects, causes, words, numbers, colours, actions and minds?

teaching/philosophical_issues_behavioura.title: Untitled
teaching/philosophical_issues_behavioura.summary: --- title: "Philosophical Issues in Behavioural Science: From Individual to Collaborative Action" url: "https://philosophical-issues-in-behavioural-science. butterfill. com/" authors: Stephen A.

teaching/philosophical_psychology.title: Untitled
teaching/philosophical_psychology.summary: --- title: "Philosophical Psychology: A Partial Survey of Puzzling Questions about Minds in Action" url: "https://philosophical-psychology-bochum. butterfill. com/" authors: Stephen A. Butterfill year: 2018-2019 term: Spring place: Ruhr-Universität Bochum, Germany.

teaching/social_cognition.title: Untitled
teaching/social_cognition.summary: --- title: "Social Cognition" url: "https://social-cognition. butterfill. com/" authors: Stephen A. Butterfill year: 2017-2018 term: Spring place: University of Warwick, UK abstract: | Social cognition is an umbrella term for the processes involved in discriminating, predicting and understanding others’ thoughts, emotions and actions.

teaching/two_systems_corrado.title: Are Two Systems Better Than One?
teaching/two_systems_corrado.summary: Two systems theories of reasoning are well-known and widely discussed. However less attention has been paid to two systems (or dual process) theories in other domains. What are two systems theories, and in which domains are they defensible?

teaching/words_and_things.title: Untitled
teaching/words_and_things.summary: --- title: "Words and Things" url: "https://words-and-things. butterfill. com/" authors: Stephen A. Butterfill year: 2018-2019 term: Autumn place: University of Warwick, UK abstract: | What links words and thoughts to objects? This is a course on the philosophy of language and mind.

writing/apperly2025_mindreading.title: Mindreading is an Asynchronous Joint Activity: The M-a-J-a Account of Theory of Mind Performance, and Individual Differences
writing/apperly2025_mindreading.summary: Research on mindreading has been dominated by questions about the presence, absence or nature of mindreading concepts or structures, and by paradigms designed to create the most favourable circumstances for demonstrating such abilities. This focus on competence has led to a neglect of questions about performance.

writing/awareness_of_belief.title: Awareness of Belief
writing/awareness_of_belief.summary: Is it possible to appreciate how different people may have beliefs different from one's own (including beliefs which are inconsistent with one's own beliefs) without understanding what it is for beliefs to be true or false? In this paper I argue that it is.

writing/blueprint_social_animal.title: Towards a Blueprint for a Social Animal
writing/blueprint_social_animal.summary: In this chapter, we attempt to answer the question, By what steps could members of a group capable of acting together with a purpose, coordinating flexibly, communicating cooperatively and deceiving competitors be constructed from creatures with minimal social skills and cognitive abilities?

writing/bpd_social_media.title: Interpersonal Functioning in Borderline Personality Disorder Traits: A Social Media Perspective
writing/bpd_social_media.summary: This is the first study to demonstrate interpersonal difficulties associated with borderline personality disorder (BPD) features in the domain of social media.

writing/butterfill2017_coordinating.title: Coordinating Joint Action
writing/butterfill2017_coordinating.summary:
This is a slightly extended version of published chapter. (The pdf is the chapter version. )

Introduction

It is often necessary that agents’ actions are coordinated if they are to successfully exercise shared (or ‘collective’) agency in acting together.

writing/butterfill2024_machines.title: What Mindreading Reveals about the Mental Lives of Machines

writing/butterfill2025_three.title: Three strategies for shared intention: plural, aggregate and reductive
writing/butterfill2025_three.summary: When deciding on a strategy for explicating shared intention, we all face two fundamental questions. First, can an intention or any other mental state have more than one subject? A positive answer to this allows the plural subject strategy: shared intention is a matter of there being one mental state with two or more subjects.

writing/chennells2022_coordinated.title: Coordinated decision-making boosts altruistic motivation—But not trust
writing/chennells2022_coordinated.summary: In the current study, we separately tested whether coordinated decision-making increases altruism and whether it increases trust. To this end, we implemented a paradigm in which participants repeatedly perform a coordinated decision-making task either with the same partner on every trial, or with a different partner on each trial.

writing/childrens_selective_learning_fro.title: Children’s Selective Learning from Others
writing/childrens_selective_learning_fro.summary: Psychological research into children's sensitivity to testimony has primarily focused on their ability to judge the likely reliability of speakers. However, verbal testimony is only one means by which children learn from others.

writing/clarke2019_joint.title: Joint Action Goals Reduce Visuomotor Interference Effects from a Partner’s Incongruent Actions
writing/clarke2019_joint.summary: Joint actions often require agents to track others’ actions while planning and executing physically incongruent actions of their own. Previous research has indicated that this can lead to visuomotor interference effects when it occurs outside of joint action. How is this avoided or overcome in joint actions?

writing/cognitive_architecture_belief_re.title: Cognitive Architecture of Belief Reasoning in Children and Adults: A Primer on the Two-Systems Account
writing/cognitive_architecture_belief_re.summary: Characterizing the cognitive architecture of human mindreading forces us to address two puzzles in people’s attributions of belief: why children show inconsistent expectations about others’ belief-based actions, and why adults’ belief reasoning is sometimes automatic and sometimes not.

writing/collective_goals.title: Towards a Mechanistically Neutral Account of Acting Jointly: The Notion of a Collective Goal
writing/collective_goals.summary: Anyone who has ever walked, cooked or crafted with a friend is in a position to know that acting jointly is not just acting side-by-side. But what distinguishes acting jointly from acting in parallel yet merely individually? Four decades of philosophical research have yielded broad consensus on a strategy for answering this question.

writing/cue_competition_effects.title: Cue Competition Effects and Young Children's Causal and Counterfactual Inferences
writing/cue_competition_effects.summary: The authors examined cue competition effects in young children using the blicket detector paradigm, in which objects are placed either singly or in pairs on a novel machine and children must judge which objects have the causal power to make the machine work. Cue competition effects were found in a 5- to 6-year-old group but not in a 4-year-old group.

writing/dellagatta2017_drawn.title: Drawn Together: When Motor Representations Ground Joint Actions
writing/dellagatta2017_drawn.summary: What enables individuals to act together? Recent discoveries suggest that a variety of mechanisms are involved. But something fundamental is yet to be investigated. In joint action, agents represent a collective goal, or so it is often assumed.

writing/developing_mind.title: The Developing Mind: A Philosophical Introduction
writing/developing_mind.summary: <html> <head> <style type="text/css"> #page-container { / PDF container / position:absolute; / required for calculating relative positions of pages in pdf2htmlEX. js / top:0; left:0px; margin:0; padding:0; border:0; / required for lazy page loading in pdf2htmlEX.

writing/fizke_limits.title: Are There Signature Limits in Early Theory of Mind?
writing/fizke_limits.summary: Current theory-of-mind research faces the challenge of reconciling two sets of seemingly incompatible findings: Whereas children come to solve explicit verbal false belief (FB) tasks from around 4 years of age, recent studies with various less explicit measures such as looking time, anticipatory looking, and spontaneous behavior suggest that even infants can…

writing/gaining_knowledge_via_other_mind.title: Gaining Knowledge via Other Minds: Children's Flexible Trust in Others as Sources of Information
writing/gaining_knowledge_via_other_mind.summary: In five experiments, we examined 3- to 6-year-olds' understanding that they could gain knowledge indirectly from someone who had seen something they had not. Consistent with previous research, children judged that an informant, who had seen inside a box, knew its contents.

writing/goals_targets.title: Goals and Targets: A Developmental Puzzle about Sensitivity to Others’ Actions
writing/goals_targets.summary: Sensitivity to others’ actions is essential for social animals like humans and a fundamental requirement for any kind of social cognition. Unsurprisingly, it is present in humans from early in the first year of life. But what processes underpin infants’ sensitivity to others’ actions?

writing/infants_representations_of_causa.title: Infants' Representations of Causation (Commentary on Susan Carey, The Origin of Concepts)
writing/infants_representations_of_causa.summary: It is consistent with the evidence in The Origin of Concepts to conjecture that infants' causal representations, like their numerical representations, are not continuous with adults', so that bootstrapping is needed in both cases.

writing/intention_motor.title: Intention and Motor Representation in Purposive Action
writing/intention_motor.summary: Are there distinct roles for intention and motor representation in explaining the purposiveness of action? Standard accounts of action assign a role to intention but are silent on motor representation.

writing/interacting_mindreaders.title: Interacting Mindreaders
writing/interacting_mindreaders.summary: Could interacting mindreaders be in a position to know things which they would be unable to know if they were manifestly passive observers? This paper argues that they could. Mindreading is sometimes reciprocal: the mindreader's target reciprocates by taking the mindreader as a target for mindreading.

writing/intuitions_about_joint_commitmen.title: Untitled
writing/intuitions_about_joint_commitmen.summary: In what sense is commitment essential to joint action, and do the participants in a joint action themselves perceive commitment as essential? Attempts to answer this question have so far been hampered by clashes of intuition. Perhaps this is because the intuitions in question have mostly been investigated using informal methods only.

writing/joint_action_development.title: Joint Action and Development
writing/joint_action_development.summary: Given the premise that joint action plays some role in explaining how humans come to understand minds, what could joint action be? Not what a leading account, Michael Bratman's, says it is.

writing/joint_action_rpp_edited_volume.title: Joint Action: What Is Shared?
writing/joint_action_rpp_edited_volume.summary:
Description

A collection of papers by philosophers and cognitive scientists on joint action and shared intention.

Contents

  1. Stephen A. Butterfill and Natalie Sebanz: Editorial: Joint Action: What Is Shared?
  2. Dorit Wenke, Silke Atmaca, Antje Hollnder: What is Shared in Joint Action?

writing/joint_action_rpp_special_issue.title: Joint Action: What Is Shared?  Introduction to the special issue
writing/joint_action_rpp_special_issue.summary: Joint action raises a tangle of philosophical, developmental and cognitive questions. Many of these questions are naturally understood to be about sharing, about the sharing of intentions, emotions, task representations, and action plans. Of course it is not easy to explain what it means to share in this context.

writing/level_2.title: Direct and indirect measures of Level-2 perspective-taking in children and adults
writing/level_2.summary: Studies with infants show divergence between performance on theory of mind tasks depending on whether direct or indirect measures are used.

writing/low2023_view.title: A view from mindreading on fast-and-slow thinking
writing/low2023_view.summary: De Neys’ incisive critique of empirical and theoretical research on the exclusivity feature underscores the depth of the challenge of explaining the interplay of fast and slow processes.

writing/mindreading_balance.title: Mindreading in the Balance: Adults’ Mediolateral Leaning and Anticipatory Looking Foretell Others’ Action Preparation in a False-Belief Interactive Task
writing/mindreading_balance.summary: Anticipatory looking on mindreading tasks can indicate our expectation of an agent's action. The challenge is that social situations are often more complex, involving instances where we need to track an agent's false belief to successfully identify the outcome to which an action is directed.

writing/minimal_brains_discussion_intro.title: Introduction: Symposium on ‘How to Constuct a Minimal Theory of Mind’
writing/minimal_brains_discussion_intro.summary:
The target paper is here: How to Construct a Minimal Theory of Mind

There are commentaries by Hannes Rakoczy [pdf],

writing/minimal_brains_discussion_replie.title: Replies to Three Commentaries on ‘How to Construct a Minimal Theory of Mind’
writing/minimal_brains_discussion_replie.summary: We are grateful to Hannes Rakoczy, Shannon Spaulding and Tadeusz Zawidzki for three illuminating and very helpful critical commentaries. Here we report some of what we have learned from them and answer the objections.

writing/minimal_theory_of_mind.title: How to Construct a Minimal Theory of Mind
writing/minimal_theory_of_mind.summary: What could someone represent that would enable her to track, at least within limits, others' perceptions, knowledge states and beliefs including false beliefs? An obvious possibility is that she might represent these very attitudes as such. It is sometimes tacitly or explicitly assumed that this is the only possible answer.

writing/modularity.title: What are Modules and What Is Their Role in Development?
writing/modularity.summary: Modules are widely held to play a central role in explaining mental development and in accounts of the mind generally. But there is much disagreement about what modules are, which shows that we do not adequately understand modularity. This paper outlines a Fodoresque approach to understanding one type of modularity.

writing/motor_representation_action_expe.title: Motor Representation and Action Experience in Joint Action
writing/motor_representation_action_expe.summary: Acting together with a purpose is a familiar feature of everyday life. We jump together, play music together and move tables together. But what do we experience of action in acting together?

writing/motor_representation_in_goal_asc.title: Motor Representation in Goal Ascription
writing/motor_representation_in_goal_asc.summary: Goal ascription, the process of identifying outcomes to which purposive actions are directed, is indispensable for predicting others’ behaviours and understanding their minds. But which mechanisms underpin goal ascription? This chapter examines several ways in which motor representations and processes are involved in different forms of goal ascription.

writing/motor_representation_skill.title: Motor Representation and Knowledge of Skilled Action
writing/motor_representation_skill.summary: If you are more skilled in performing certain actions, you are probably also better able to acquire knowledge when observing those actions. Why are performance skills so connected to observation skills?

writing/mummification.title: Visibly constraining an agent modulates observers’ automatic false-belief tracking
writing/mummification.summary: Our motor system can generate representations which carry information about the goals of another agent’s actions. However, it is not known whether motor representations play a deeper role in social understanding, and, in particular, whether they enable tracking others’ beliefs.

writing/pascarelli2024_principles.title: Principles of belief acquisition. How we read other minds
writing/pascarelli2024_principles.summary: Reading other minds is a pervasive feature of human social life. A decade of research indicates that people can automatically track an agent’s beliefs regardless of whether this is required. But little is known about the principles t guide automatic belief tracking. In six experiments adapting a false belief task introduced by Kovacs et al.

writing/perceiving_expressions_emotion.title: Perceiving Expressions of Emotion: What evidence could bear on questions about perceptual experience of mental states?
writing/perceiving_expressions_emotion.summary: What evidence could bear on questions about whether humans ever perceptually experience any of another’s mental states, and how might those questions be made precise enough to test experimentally? This paper focusses on emotions and their expression.

writing/planning_for_collective_agency.title: Planning for Collective Agency
writing/planning_for_collective_agency.summary: Which planning mechanisms enable agents to coordinate their actions, and what if anything do these tell us about the nature of collective agency? On the leading, best developed account, Michael Bratman's, collective agency is explained in terms of interconnected planning.

writing/primal_self.title: From foraging to autonoetic consciousness: The primal self as a consequence of embodied prospective foraging
writing/primal_self.summary: The capacity to adapt to resource distributions by modulating the frequency of exploratory and exploitative behaviors is common across metazoans and is arguably a principal selective force in the evolution of cognition.

writing/psychological_research_on_joint_.title: Psychological Research on Joint Action: Theory and Data
writing/psychological_research_on_joint_.summary: When two or more people coordinate their actions in space and time to produce a joint outcome, they perform a joint action.

writing/puzzle_thought_experience_motori.title: On a Puzzle about Relations between Thought, Experience and the Motoric
writing/puzzle_thought_experience_motori.summary: Motor representations live a kind of double life. Although paradigmatically involved in performing actions, they also occur when merely observing others act and sometimes influence thoughts about the goals of observed actions.

writing/review_consciousness.title: Review of Consciousness: New Philosophical Perspectives. Edited by Quentin Smith and Aleksander Jokic

writing/review_joint_commitment.title: Review of Joint Commitment: How We Make the Social World by Margaret Gilbert

writing/review_self-knowing_agents.title: Review of Self-Knowing Agents by Lucy O'Brien
writing/review_self-knowing_agents.summary: The first-person is "expressive of self-consciousness" (64). Someone who uses the first-person, for example in saying or thinking "Where am I? ", not only succeeds in referring to herself but also knows that she refers to herself.

writing/review_the_rational_imagination.title: Review of The Rational Imagination by Ruth Byrne
writing/review_the_rational_imagination.summary: This book develops a mental models approach to counterfactual thinking. It brings together a large body of empirical research by the author and collaborators, and interprets the findings in the light of some novel views about meaning.

writing/review_thinking_without_words.title: Review of Thinking without Words by Jose Luis Bermudez
writing/review_thinking_without_words.summary: That some animals, early hominids and infants think (or did so once) is increasingly hard to doubt. Our evidence includes everything from the manufacture and use of tools (55, 127), to the ways infants react when shown apparently impossible physical events (81). Bermdez' project is to explain the nature of this thinking.

writing/seeing_causes.title: Seeing Causes and Hearing Gestures
writing/seeing_causes.summary:
Abstract

Can humans see causal interactions? This paper argues that evidence on the visual perception of causal interactions, from Michotte to contemporary work, is best interpreted as showing that we can see some causal interactions in the same sense that we can hear speech.

writing/seeing_it_both_ways.title: Seeing It Both Ways: Using a Double-Cuing Task to Investigate the Role of Spatial Cuing in Level-1 Visual Perspective-Taking
writing/seeing_it_both_ways.summary: Previous research using the dot-perspective task has produced evidence that humans may be equipped with a mechanism that spontaneously tracks others’ gaze direction and thereby acquires information about what they can see.

writing/sinigaglia2022_motor.title: Motor Representation in Acting Together
writing/sinigaglia2022_motor.summary:
Abstract

People walk, build, paint and otherwise act together with a purpose in myriad ways. What is the relation between the actions people perform in acting together with a purpose and the outcome, or outcomes, to which their actions are directed?

writing/szekely2024_effortbased.title: Effort-based decision making in joint action: Evidence of a sense of fairness
writing/szekely2024_effortbased.summary: As humans, we are unique with respect to the flexibility and scope of our cooperative behavior. In recent years, considerable research has been devoted to investigating the psychological mechanisms which support this.

writing/taking_apart.title: Taking Apart What Brings Us Together: The Role of Action Prediction, Perspective-Taking, and Theory of Mind in Joint Action
writing/taking_apart.summary: The ability to act together with others to achieve common goals is crucial in life, yet there is no full consensus on the underlying cognitive skills.

writing/tool_use_book.title: Tool Use and Causal Cognition
writing/tool_use_book.summary:
Description

A collection of essays by philosophers and cognitive scientists on tool use and causal cognition.

Contents

  1. Teresa McCormack, Christoph Hoerl, & Stephen A. Butterfill: Tool Use and Causal Cognition: An Introduction
  2. Jim Woodward: A Philosopher Looks at Tool Use and Causal Understanding
  3. Melissa L.

writing/tracking_representing_mental_sta.title: Tracking and Representing Others’ Mental States
writing/tracking_representing_mental_sta.summary: Few things matter more than the mental states of those nearby. Their ignorance defines limits on cooperation and presents opportunities to exploit in competition. (If she’s seen where you stashed those mealworms she’ll pilfer them when you’re gone, leaving you without breakfast. And you won’t get that grape if he hears you sneaking past.

writing/two_kinds_of_purposive_action.title: Two Kinds of Purposive Action
writing/two_kinds_of_purposive_action.summary: It is normally assumed that there is only one kind of purposive action. This article argues that there are two kinds of purposive action, which require different models of explanation. One kind of action is done without awareness of reasons; another kind of action is done because the agent is aware of reasons for that action.

writing/two_systems.title: Do Humans Have Two Systems to Track Beliefs and Belief-like States?
writing/two_systems.summary: The lack of consensus on how to characterize humans' capacity for belief reasoning has been brought into sharp focus by recent research. Children fail critical tests of belief reasoning before 3 to 4 years of age (H. Wellman, D. Cross, & J.

writing/two_systems_goal_ascription.title: Is Goal Ascription Possible in Minimal Mindreading?
writing/two_systems_goal_ascription.summary: In this response to the commentary by Michael and Christensen, we first explain how minimal mindreading is compatible with the development of increasingly sophisticated mindreading behaviours that involve both executive functions and general knowledge, and then sketch one approach to a minimal account of goal ascription.

writing/vesper_minimal_2010.title: A Minimal Architecture for Joint Action
writing/vesper_minimal_2010.summary: What kinds of processes and representations make joint action possible? In this paper, we suggest a minimal architecture for joint action that focuses on representations, action monitoring and action prediction processes, as well as ways of simplifying coordination.

writing/what_does_knowledge_explain.title: What Does Knowledge Explain? Commentary on Jennifer Nagel
writing/what_does_knowledge_explain.summary: Knowledge is a mental state: Nagel may be right about this but wrong to suppose that knowledge is prior to belief in the sense that being able to recognize belief somehow depends on having a concept of knowledge. This commentary identifies objections to Nagel's arguments for priority.

writing/zani2023_mindreading.title: Mindreading by body: incorporating mediolateral balance and mouse-tracking measures to examine the motor basis of adults’ false-belief tracking
writing/zani2023_mindreading.summary: The role played by motor representations in tracking others belief-based actions remains unclear.
